Package com.tiyb.tev.datamodel

This package contains the @Entity classes for working with data in the DB.

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    Answer
    Encapsulates the data needed for a Tumblr "Answer" style of post
    Link
    Encapsulates the data needed for a Tumblr "Link" style of post
    Metadata
    Encapsulates metadata stored in the database for use by the application.
    Photo
    Encapsulates the data needed for a Tumblr "Photo" style of post
    Post
    Encapsulates the data for any Tumblr post.
    Regular
    Encapsulates the data needed for a Tumblr "Regular" style of post (just a normal text post)
    Type
    Encapsulates the different "types" of post that are available for Tumblr
    Video
    Encapsulates the data needed for a Tumblr "Video" style of post

Package com.tiyb.tev.datamodel Description

This package contains the @Entity classes for working with data in the DB.

The data model is built around the concept of posts; in Tumblr, there are various kinds of post (Answer, Link, Photo, Regular, or Video); there is common data that occurs for every post (e.g. URL of the post, date/time the post went live), as well as content that is specific to the individual type. For this reason, the classes here include a Post class, which is used for every post, as well as individual classes for the post types.

To properly enact this, there are tables in the underlying database to represent each type of post, as well as a central table for all posts. The individual tables link back to the main post entry, via foreign keys. The application "cheats" here, a little, bit, whereby the foreign key for each child table is also the primary key for that table; this is possible since there is a one-to-one relationship between the tables (each record in the individual tables links back to one and only one post). (The exception is the table for holding photos, since there can be multiple photos associated with a given post. For this reason, the photo entity has a primary key, as well as the foreign key to the post.)

The other tables/classes represented here are for metadata (data that didn't come from the Tumblr export, but which is needed for the application to run), as well as a list of post types. The latter could have been hard-coded into the application -- there are only 5 -- but it was decided to keep things generic, and make the types table-driven.

Author:
tiyb
